holdings.text: The judgment-debtors applicants were entitled to the benefit of the U.P. Debt Redemption Act, 1940, under section 8 as all three pre-requisites were satisfied: they are agriculturists, liable under a decree to which the Act applies passed before commencement.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the wording of the sub-section that there are three pre-requisites for exercise of the right conferred by it, namely, ( 1 ) that the application must be by an agriculturist and  2 that that agriculturist must be liable to pay the amount due under a decree to which this Act applies and  3  that that decree was passed before the commencement of this Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of s8(1); agriculturist status conceded; decree pre-commencement; applies to loan-related suit.

holdings.text: The decree was passed in a suit relating to a loan as defined under section 2(17) and 2(9), hence the Act applies per section 2(6).

anchor.surface_text: Section 2(17) defines the phrase suit to which this Act applies as meaning any suit or proceeding relating to a loan. The question then, arises was the decree under which the judgment-debtors applicants are liable passed in a suit relating to a loan ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definitions applied to mortgage recovery suit; advance recoverable from agriculturists.

holdings.text: Sita Ram had not ceased to be an agriculturist by reason of clause (b) of the proviso to section 2(3) as he was not assessed to income-tax on July 28, 1931.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unrebutted evidence shows first income-tax deduction February 1932, assessment 1933; salary below threshold pre-1931 Act.

holdings.text: Sita Ram was an agriculturist on all relevant dates including date of advance (1931), due date (1937), suit (1938), and application (1942).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence from witnesses and documents; no rebuttal; income below taxable limit until 1932.

holdings.text: 'Recoverable' in section 2(9) prima facie means when the advance becomes recoverable i.e. falls due.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'recoverable'; not necessary to decision as decided on other grounds.

holdings.text: Accounts correctly reopened from June 2, 1922, as mortgagees in both mortgages were the same so far as judgment-debtors concerned; point not raised in objections.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds trial court fact-finding; no objection raised; adverse inference from non-production of accounts.

anchor.surface_text: the case was fully companyered by the Full Bench decision of that High Court in Ketki Kunwar v. Ram Saroop  1 . The High Court, therefore, dismissed the appeal on this point alone. The question whether the account should be reopened from 1922 or from 1931 was number raised by the decree-holders at all. he decree-holders have number companye up on appeal before us on a certificate granted by the High Court under section 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure. Sri G.N. Kunzru appearing in support of this appeal has strongly questioned the companyrectness of the Full Bench deci- sion relied on by the High Court and the interpretation put by the High Court on section 21 and section 2  9  of the Act. As we think this appeal can be decided on a simpler ground we do number companysider it necessary, on this occasion, to express any opinion on either of these questions which are by numbermeans free from doubt. I.L.R. 1943 All. 35 A.I.R. 1942 All. 390  1942  A. J. 578.

precedents.cited_proposition: Proviso to definition of 'loan' in section 2(9) of the U.P. Debt Redemption Act has no application where by reason of section 21 mortgage amount could be recovered only from mortgaged property and not personally from mortgagors; hence not necessary to show borrowers were agriculturists at date of advance if they were agriculturists at date of suit
